definitions.definition: To imitate, often in a satirical manner.
(of an aircraft or spacecraft) To leave the ground and begin flight; to ascend into the air.
definitions.example: The plane has been cleared to take off from runway 3.
The business has really taken off this year and has made quite a profit.
I'm going to take off now.
I'll take off the concrete and steel for this construction project.

definitions.definition: To absent oneself from work or other responsibility, especially with permission.
definitions.example: He decided to let his mother take a night off from cooking, so he took her and his siblings out to dinner.

definitions.definition: To take drugs; to inject drugs.

definitions.example: to take off a glass of wine

definitions.definition: The rising or ascent of an aircraft or rocket into flight.
definitions.example: The flight was smooth, but the takeoff was a little rough.

definitions.definition: A parody or lampoon of someone or something.
A quantification, especially of building materials.
definitions.example: I'll give you an estimate after I do the quantity takeoffs for the trusses and structural steel.

definitions.definition: The removal of sheets from the press.
The spot from which one takes off; specifically, the place from which a jumper rises in leaping.
